column4: What is the correct way to hide old kernel versions from the grublist when booting?
set the "number of kernels to show" variable..
I don't really remember what it's called.. but I can't imagine it would be hard to identify if you look through the menu.lst
Should I set it to 1 or is it using any weird notation? :)
of course you could also just uninstall the older kernels.. unless you really need tham
nothing weird.. 1.. or perhaps 2.. just so you can select an earlier kernel if you really want to
don't forget to run "sudo update-grub" when you're finished.. or it won't stick
I never use old kernels - do you know how to uninstall them? I like to keep things simple :)
apt-get remove or look in synaptic
Do you know what I should look/search for @ synaptic?
the kernel packages are called linux-image bla bla bla
you can click "status" and select "installed".. that will only show installed packages
Thanks for all the advices - just one quick one: is there any risk in deleting them? I never boot using the old kernels anyway...
Oh and should I use complete removal? I probably not going to install old kernels later... :)
nah.. as long as you have a working kernel installed there is no reason to keep the old ones
I don't think it will remove the grub entries if you just remove it normally
